reasoning:
First off, Microsoft isn’t in my Circle of Competence. I’ve built my record on straightforward businesses – Coke, See’s Candies, insurance – not sprawling software platforms and cloud services. While Microsoft’s operating margins are impressive, the inconsistency in returns (only 1 of 10 years above 15% ROE) and a chunky debt‐to‐equity of 2.1 raise flags about financial fortress strength and earnings consistency.

On the moat, I’ll admit their stable 73% operating margins hint at pricing power, but inconsistent ROEs and choppy earnings growth undercut what I’d call a truly durable advantage. As for management, issuing stock and paying no meaningful dividends – according to the data – suggests capital allocation that favors expansion over returning cash to owners. That’s fine in growth businesses, but it’s not my style unless there’s a huge margin of safety.

Speaking of valuation, the three‐stage DCF pegs intrinsic value around $42,000 after a conservative haircut, yet the current price implies a negative 94% margin of safety. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price. Microsoft today looks expensive for the uncertainties in growth and returns.

Long term, software will matter, but I’m uncomfortable forecasting cloud and AI economics over decades. Compare this to Coca-Cola’s brand moat or our insurance float at GEICO – those are businesses I not only understand but can value with confidence. In short, I’ll pass on Microsoft and wait for a simpler business with a real margin of safety.
